title: 104_s1150
content: The Act is titled the "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" and specifies the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue commemorative coins for the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan and George Catlett Marshall. This includes 700,000 one dollar silver coins and 500,000 half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under the United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan and feature George C. Marshall. The coins will also include inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "1997", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the George C. Marshall Foundation, Friends of George C. Marshall, and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary has the authority to begin issuing these coins on January 1, 1997, but minting must cease by December 31, 1997. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges of $12 per coin will be included in all sales. The one dollar coin will be sold for $12 per coin, and the half dollar coin will be sold for $4 per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales under this Act will be divided equally between the George C. Marshall Foundation for educational programs and the Friends of George C. Marshall for the construction of a memorial center. The Comptroller General can audit the Foundation and Friends for expenditure oversight. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is given.
